awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Upskilling Craftspeople to Prepare for the Future of End-user Driven Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier Planning (FW-HTF-P) grant will focus on a preliminary study to gather information on challenges and opportunities for promoting craftspeople to participate in the future manufacturing workforce. It also contributes to an integrative research framework with stakeholders in crafts to push forward the frontier technology. This project will build a multi-disciplinary team to create new knowledge in three diverse areas that advance impacts on end-user fabrication, human-computer interaction, culture and learning, and social psychology. Through this planning grant, the team aims to characterize the craft end-users, their challenges, barriers, and opportunity to serve as the future manufacturing workforce at home given the technology and proper training that the research will result in. It will promote a new research framework and validation that collaborations between researchers and practitioners in crafts can push science and technology forward. The iterative technology development process identifies technologies that challenge existing patterns of workers and society, by reflecting the real-world needs and barriers of craftspeople at various levels and adapting current craft practices.

This project builds a team across several disciplines to establish the foundational knowledge and build metrics to measure the success of end-user manufacturing. The team will identify consumer-caring product properties through in-the-wild surveys, in addition to the partnership with the Houston Center for Craft to reach professional craftspeople who are affiliated with the center, identifying customization needs, ideal workflows, and critical design parameters that need to be supported through end-user software tool for custom 3D printing. The project will result in a preliminary understanding of the interplay between material response and processing parameters (e.g., printing speed, material layout, etc.) in 3D printed object’s stiffness and strength, to computationally customize them in composite polymers using accessible machines and materials. This research will reshape the manufacturing pipeline through novel techniques and end-user support tools in which the end-user specifies custom needs and individual end-user manufacturers can process them to produce personalized products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier Planning (FW-HTF-P) project investigated methods to transform craft workers, preparing them for future manufacturing workforce, and to foster technology development to invite previously non-labor market participants into home-based small business.


The team secured preliminary studies about fine-tunning mechanical properties of 3D printed consumer products using low-cost, consumer grade 3D printers at local studios. This project supported team building for putting together an integrative research framework. The project consisted of three major research activities, (1) performing experimental and computational studies to predict programmable mechanical properties in 3D printed structures using metamaterials, (2) developing potential consumer products in medical/health care domains that need highly customizable products per different user needs and comfort, wearable sensors that can measure the degrees of body movement freedom during physical recover, grip force recovery device, and (3) creating connections with education partners for team meetings, Haystack Mountain School of Craft, and Houston Center for Contemporary Craft. To support open source editors for non-experts, the team developed a high-level design space of 3D printed tunable mechanical properties, which will be integrated into an intelligent user interface as an input and output through simulations. 


The project has led to six (6) full papers, two (2) at the rigorously peer-reviewed top venues in Human-Computer Interaction and Computer Science ACM CHI and ACM TEI, four (4) highly impactful journal papers, led by five (5) PhD students in Computer Science, Mechanical Engineering, and the College of Architecture. Among them, 1 female student, which is underrepresented minorities in Computing, was supported. One dissertation fellowship application was submitted and is under review based on the preliminary result. The project was disseminated to the wider audiences of interest, current craft professionals who are not familiar with the cutting edge technology, through Society of North American Goldsmith (SNAG) conference, which was held in San Diego in June 2024. 


 


Last Modified: 12/05/2024
Modified by: Jeeeun Kim
